Technical Report
Exmibal Nickel Project
Prepared for:
Skye Resources Inc.
by:
Dominique François Bongarçon, Ph.D.
Brian Montpellier, P.Eng
141973
CERTIFICATE OF AUTHOR
Brian Montpellier, P. Eng
4110 W. 15th Avenue
Vancouver, BC   V6R 3A5
Tel: (604) 664-4710 
Fax: (604) 664-3301
brian.montpellier@amec.com
I, Brian Montpellier, P. Eng., am a Professional Engineer of AMEC E&C Services Limited of 
4110 W 15th Avenue, in the City of Vancouver in the Province of British Columbia. 
 
I  am  a  member  of  the  Association  of  Professional  Engineers  and  Geoscientists  of  British 
Columbia.  I graduated from the University of British Columbia with a Bachelor of Science 
(Honours)  degree  in  Chemistry  in  1970  and  I  have  practiced  my  profession  continuously 
since 1973. 
 
Since 1973 I have been involved in: mineral development projects for nickel, molybdenum, 
copper,  zinc,  gold  and  silver  in  Indonesia,  Venezuela,  Spain,  Peru,  Mexico,  West  Africa, 
Canada, and the United States.   
 
As  a  result  of  my  experience  and  qualification,  I  am  a  Qualified  Person  as  defined  in 
NI 43-101. 
 
I am presently a Senior Project Manager and have been so since 1983. 
 
On the 14th and 15th of January 2003, Dr. Bongarçon and I visited the Exmibal Nickel Project 
in Guatemala for the purposes of reviewing pertinent geological, mining and infrastructure. 
 
This report was prepared under my direct supervision in consultation with another technical 
specialist, who is a Qualified Person in the field of geostatistics and resource determination.   
 
I am not aware of any material fact or material change with respect to the subject matter of 
this  technical  report,  which  is  not  reflected  in  this  report,  the  omission  to  disclose  which 
would make this report misleading.

Sciences & Technology, University of Nancy.

mining properties around the world.

NI 43-101.

infrastructure.

This  report  was  prepared  as  a  National  Instrument  43-101 
Technical  Report,  in  accordance  to  Form  43-101F1,  for  Skye 
Resources Inc. (Skye) by AMEC E&C Services Limited (AMEC).  
The  quality  of  information, conclusions and estimates contained 
herein  is  consistent  with  the  level  of  effort  involved  in  AMEC’s 
services  and  based  on:  i)  information  available  at  the  time  of 
preparation,  ii)  data  supplied  by  outside  sources,  and  iii)  the 
assumptions, conditions, and qualifications set forth in this report.  
This report is intended to be used by Ivanhoe, subject to the terms 
and conditions of its contract with AMEC.  This contract permits 
Skye  to  file  this  report  as  a  Technical  Report  with  Canadian 
Securities Regulatory Authorities pursuant to National Instrument 
43-101, Standards of Disclosure for Mineral Projects.  Any other 
use of this report by any third party is at that party’s sole risk.

14.0  DATA VERIFICATION
14.1
Database Verification
AMEC first performed random spot checks of the available drill hole logs against the 
computer drill hole assay database to quantify the likely rate of errors.  A total of 304 
records from 21 drill holes drilled between 1965 and 1978 were checked for nickel, 
iron and cobalt and a systematic mismatch on nickel and cobalt was found in the data 
drilled up to 30 September 1976, while posterior holes all matched perfectly for all 
three grades.
In this exercise, the following drill holes were checked by database index number:
22744 and 22745  
22815 and 22816 
22398 and 22390 
22339 and 22340 
22309 and 22310 
22081 
22191 
22336 
22273 
22200, 22333, and 22208
July 1978 
August 1978 
May 1977 
January 1977 
December 1976 
December 1975 
August 1976 
October 1976 
November 1976 
September 1976
Collar surveys and the topography were not checked.
14.1.1  Pre-October 1976 Drill Holes
With a few exceptions, the mismatches between the two types of data were found to 
be systematic before October 1976.  These affected only nickel and cobalt grades, 
never iron.  Transcription errors were ruled out as the explanation and the investigation 
was focused on some re-assaying or error correction process.
It was discovered that the existing database had been corrected for nickel and cobalt 
using regression equations to overcome the pitfalls of the titration method used in 
older assay data.  Significant evidence of the work leading to these corrections was 
found in numerous memoranda at Inco.
There remains some doubt as to the exact decision tree used to correct the assay data 
depending on the grade ranges, sample types, and rock type.  Instead, a number of
141973 
December 2003
Page 14-1
SKYE RESOURCES INC. 
T e c h n i c a l
  R e p o r t
E x m i b a l   N i c k e l   P r o j e c t
proposals  for  action  with  associated  discussion  comments  were  found  in  Inco’s 
documentation.  AMEC believes not all of the formulas used have been found.  AMEC 
was able to reconstitute all grades checked within a maximum one point at the second 
decimal position.
The work by Inco was found to have been performed using industry standard methods 
by recognized professionals and is believed to be a positive contribution to assay 
accuracy.
The difference between the original and database nickel grades is not large, on five 
drill holes from 1975 it was estimated to globally amount to a mere 0.8% of the nickel 
present, the original grades being slightly higher.  Without the exact equations, drill 
holes from before October 1976 could not be checked for transcription errors.  As they 
were  obviously  the  objects  of  this  comprehensive  work,  it  is  believed  that  any 
inordinate number of errors, if they existed, would have been found and corrected.
14.1.2  Post-October 1976 Drill Holes
An additional 682 records, representing the totality of holes drilled during the month of 
September 1978, were then checked for nickel, iron and occasionally cobalt and no 
discrepancies were found between the paper logs and the computer database.
14.2
Density Studies
Overall, dry densities of 1.08 g/cm3 for the saprolite and 0.96 g/cm3 for the limonite 
were used.
No densities were derived by rock type, but they should be developed before resource 
conversion to reserves.
According to Inco, there was an excellent reconciliation of tonnes and grades between 
the MRI and plant production.  A lack of more detailed density studies is not a concern 
at this point for resource reporting.  AMEC recommends revisiting density derivations 
before the building of a final reserve estimate.
141973 
December 2003
Page 14-2
SKYE RESOURCES INC. 
T e c h n i c a l
  R e p o r t
E x m i b a l   N i c k e l   P r o j e c t
20.0  CONCLUSIONS
AMEC has reached the following conclusions:
•  The database integrity appears to be acceptable to excellent. 
•  The  resource  modelling  methodology  is  acceptable  since  the  grade  of 
mineralization in the laterite is not very variable.  The bedrock topography should 
be refined using GPR and geostatistical estimation methods should be used for 
any subsequent estimations (resources or reserves).
•  Although a mine plan exists and production has taken place, a final mine plan 
would be required that would reflect the results of the contemplated metallurgical 
process.
•  Existing resource classification would have needed more supporting studies to be 
accepted  with  respect  to  the  NI  43-101  guidelines,  but  as  AMEC  reduced  the 
Measured category to a drill density on a 25 m grid, the reporting is adequate as 
per Section 2.1.
•  Certain  parts  of  the  existing  plant  and  infrastructure  should  be  able  to  be 
incorporated into an alternative process, subject to economic verification in a study.
AMEC offers the following recommendations for further work, and especially for final 
reserve reporting:
•  Check topography, drill hole collar surveys. 
•
If  possible,  locate  additional  information  on sample preparation, assaying, and 
QA/QC at the various successive laboratories, as well as the exact corrections that 
were brought to nickel and cobalt in the database.
•  Obtain and analyse various model reconciliations performed over the years. 
•  Estimate densities per rock type and build a density block model. 
•  Determine the extent of limonite data in the Exmibal archives and develop a plan to
confirm this resource.
•  Upgrade the overall resource classification status using ground penetrating radar to
map the bedrock contact.
•  Build a new geostatistical resource model appropriate for conversion to reserves. 
•  Convert to reserves in full knowledge of final mining and process parameters.
141973 
December 2003
Page 20-1
SKYE RESOURCES INC. 
T e c h n i c a l
  R e p o r t
E x m i b a l   N i c k e l   P r o j e c t
•  Use geostatistical conditional simulations and very close space drilling to support 
the  final  resource  classification  scheme.    A  more  modern  grade  interpolation 
method should be used.
141973 
December 2003
Page 20-2
SKYE RESOURCES INC. 
T e c h n i c a l
  R e p o r t
E x m i b a l   N i c k e l   P r o j e c t

Minimum
*Note:  A  simple  comparison  between  the  input  (declustered  composite)  data  and  the  OK  model  is  not  possible  in  the  transition 
horizon due to the variable and generally very thin nature of this horizon.  The variable thickness results in the presence of drill holes 
in portions of the deposit which are too thin to be filled by a 12.5 m x 12.5 m x 2.5 m block.  Direct comparisons between input 
composites and block model grade data will therefore induce a systematic bias because of the variable degree of information.  Input 
drill composite data for the transition horizon have therefore been interpolated into the same model prototype that was used for the 
OK  model,  using  the  Nearest  Neighbour  technique.    Global  results  of  the  NN  model  (which  represent  the  declustered  input 
composited data) were then compared with the OK model for the purposes of transition horizon model validation.
